sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Powered by market hype, trends among youth, and enormous funds, wearable technology has propelled itself as one of the most discussed topics in the field during past few years. A number of different companies representing all throughout the world have already entered into the market with hundreds of different products like smart watches, fitness trackers, smart garments, and even different smart medical attachments.
Together with the evolution of digital health care, the wearable electronics field has evolved rapidly during the past few years and is expected to be expanded even further within the first few years of the next decade. As the next stage of wearables is predicted to move toward integrated wearables, nanomaterials and nanocomposites are in the spotlight of the search for novel concepts for integration. In addition, the conversion of current devices and attachment-based wearables into integrated technology may involve a significant size reduction while retaining their functional capabilities. Nanomaterialbased wearable sensors have already marked their presence with a significant distinction while nanomaterial-based wearable actuators are still at their embryonic stage. This review looks into the contribution of nanomaterials and nanocomposites to wearable technology with a focus on wearable sensors and actuators.

The market has already evolved beyond health care, fitness and wellness of humans into infotainment, and commercial and industrial applications.[1] Since the market is expected to grow from its current value of USD 40 billion to an enormous value of USD 160 billion by 2026, the potential for novel concepts of wearable technologies is clearly visible.
Together with the growth of market requirement, research and development stage has also evolved during past few years. The emergence of digital medicine has also accounted for most of this evolution as it is required to monitor a patient continuously and even remotely in some cases.[2] Continuous growth of the total number of publications in this field can
be taken as an appropriate proof. Figure 1 provides a clear idea about the number of articles published under three major sections of wearable electronics (sensors, actuators, and electronics) during past 10 years. The results have been obtained from publication database of Web of Science with four keywords: wearable, sensor, actuator, and electronics.
As is highlighted,[1] wearables are shifting toward the second phase of embedded systems from their predecessor, detachable components. Textile-embedded sensors, actuators, and

And yet, the development of materials tailored to specific application is challenging as they exhibit different characteristic behaviors upon different stimuli. In this review, we are going to investigate the contribution of nanomaterial in the field of wearables. We are basically evaluating wearable electronics under two major categories: wearable actuators and wearable sensors. In each section, together with a discussion on different categories, current applications of nanomaterials in sensors and actuators will be discussed. It will then be followed by a short representation of different materials and methods being used.

sections.heading: 2.1. Overview
sections.text:
While nanomaterial sensors sense an external stimulus and convert it into measurable signal, which can later be transferred to a processing unit or a monitoring device, actuators basically react to an electrical signal or stimuli generated from a processing unit or a signal directly fetched from a sensor. Such stimuli can be developed by mechanical, thermal, chemical, or magnetic means whereas the reactions can be fallen within structural deformations,[6,11] heating,[12,13] noise, or even substance release.[14] Such kind of responding approach is significant in wearable technologies since it is capable of converting “passive” wearables into “active” or “smart” wearables.[15] However, the presence of nanocomposites or nanomaterials in wearable actuators is at its embryonic stage. They are still emerging as promising candidates in wearable actuators as current trends on smart wearables, smart clothing, and the performance enhancing fabrics can accelerate their presence in future market.[16]
In textile industry, the development of e-textiles and smart fabrics[11,14,15] has broaden the applications of wearable actuators whereas heating elements embedded in wearables,[12,17–20] nanocomposite-based therapeutic devices,[21,22] artificial muscles and muscular actuators,[10,23–26] rehabilitation devices,[27,28] and wearable drug delivery systems[29,30] have also contributed to the development of wearable actuators. A detailed description on applications in various industries will be presented in a following section.
To be incorporated into wearable and flexible electronics, the selection of material is very important. Based on their applications, they should have enough strength, structural rigidity, and flexibility and should be able to provide sufficient amount of actuating force. In addition, they should possess comfortability and biocompatibility specially for drug delivery systems and therapeutic systems. However, traditional transducer materials like piezoelectric materials, magnetostrictive materials, and quantum tunneling composites are very hard to integrate into flexible materials due to their poor flexibility.[14] In 1994, as Lewis[31] has suggested the use of dielectric materials as artificial muscles, researchers have explored different material groups and developed novel nanocomposites and other materials for wearable actuators. sections.heading: 2.2. Types of Actuators
sections.text: Generally, actuators are categorized under transducers that convert any form of electrical signal into a measurable mechanical output. When it comes to textiles and other wearable applications, actuators are described as a type of devices that exert mechanical movement, noise, or substance release upon receiving an electronic signal.[45] Even though the significance of nanomaterials in wearable actuators is not comparable with its presence in wearable sensors, it is already being used in some interesting applications. With the development of new composites, the range of applications is broadening and hence can make an interesting impact on wearable electronics. The development of smart fabrics[15] has opened up some interesting applications for wearable actuators including wearable heaters,[18,19,44] therapeutic devices,[21,22] artificial muscles,[10,25,26] and wearable drug delivery devices.[30,46,47]

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Wearable Heating Elements
sections.text:
Heating and thermal applications in wearable devices is one of the major aspects discussed under wearable electronics. Generally, two major areas can be identified as applications of wearable heating elements: personal thermal comfort and thermotherapeutic applications. Heating and cooling jackets[48] and clothes[20] have become major players in personnel thermal
management applications and even have become as fashion trends among youth. These forms of personnel thermal management approaches are essential for countries having extreme winter seasons and even useful for different sports and leisure activities like hiking, camping where the environmental conditions can get harsh.
One of the major drawbacks of traditional building heating based thermal comfort is the waste of energy consumed for heating empty space.[49] Personal thermal comfort should directly address the individual and wearable devices can make it possible as well. Hsu et al.[49] have presented a method, the dipcoat cotton fabrics with metal nanowires (NWs), to improve the thermal comfort. The presented breathable and washable cloth has claimed more than 30 times energy savings per person when compared with the traditional building heating based approach. Figure 2a shows the prepared sample of cloth and its working behavior during operation. Multifunctional and hydrophobic cloth presented by Liu et al.[50] has used infrared (IR) reflective properties of silica nanoparticle composite to prevent heat loss from the user to keep them warm during winter seasons (Figure 2b). Gao et al.[51] have prepared thermally conductive polymer based fiber and have incorporated it into a fabric to enhance the thermal conductivity. Fibers fabricated with 3D printing technology have been woven into a fabric and its enhanced thermal conductive properties has released body heat more effectively. They claimed a 55% increase in cooling effect compared with cotton fabric. Transforming commercial fabrics into wearable heating devices has eliminated most of the flexibility and breathability issues of synthesis functional fabrics. Zhang et al.[52] have coated commercial fabric with conductive polymer bath and demonstrated the heating capabilities (Figure 2c). Ilanchezhiyan et al.[7] have coated cotton fibers with functionalized CNT to fabricate yarns and fabric mats of wearable heating cloth. Yang et al.[53] have modified the facemask with nanofibers to enhance the thermal reflective properties. This will prevent any radiative heat losses/absorbances from face and will enhance the thermal comfortability.
Wearables in thermotherapeutic application are of an important use in the medical field. Thermotherapy or localized

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Actuators and Artificial Muscles
sections.text:
Under this section, the authors will discuss the type of wearable actuators that exert force or motion upon application of electronic signal generated from a sensor or a signal processing circuit. Since the possibility of integrating nanomaterials in wearable actuators has been first identified by Lewis,[31] people have started looking for possibilities to scale down those actuators into wearables. Researchers have tried to develop different material classes to be used as wearable and flexible actuator materials like dielectric elastomers,[10] fabric-based materials,[15,56] and electroactive polymers.[32,57] Maziz et al.[58] prepared conducting polymers into fabric like yarns and successfully knitted them into a “texactuator” (textile + actuator). When these yarns are knitted together, they have exhibited 53 times higher strain enhancement over woven yarn-based fabrics. When woven into a suit to be worn like exoskeleton, this fabric can be used as an assistive clothing or artificial muscle. Moreover, this type of fabric has

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Drug Delivery
sections.text:
Wearable drug delivery systems based on nanomaterials have recently become an interesting topic because of their ability to provide localized noninvasive drug delivery around the clock.[60] Basically, the integration of therapeutic career materials into functional materials can enhance the comfortability of the patient. Fabric like drug delivery systems, wearable patch like drug careers, or small-scale device like drug delivery systems are emerging as an alternative to traditional drug delivery methods.[30] Generally, four triggering mechanisms are used in drug delivery applications,[30] as in mechanically stimulated, electrically stimulated, light or thermally stimulated, and bio stimulated. Here, we will not explore bio-stimulated drug delivery systems since they are not in our scope. Stretch-triggered drug delivery patch developed by Di et al.[47] consists of drug-loaded nanoparticle depots embedded in stretchable elastomer. When applied on a stretchable skin portion like on finger joints, every finger bending action will release a predetermined amount of drug via a series of microneedles (Figure 4g). Thermally triggered drug delivery module for blood sugar controlling has also been developed and successfully tested on mice.[46] As shown in Figure 3c, hydrogels are loaded with drug and are coated with phase changing materials for controlled release of drug. Most of the thermal triggering drug delivery devices use electroresistive heaters[21] to supply and control the necessary temperature to the drug-loaded nanoparticles. Electric field can provide painless drug delivery by stimulating drug carrying nanoparticles. Lamination of drug-loaded graphene electrodes can release their drugs onto the skin with an application of electric field.[54] The drug delivery depth can easily be controlled by the number of electrical stimuli. Suggesting an alternative approach for drug-loaded needles or particles, Honda et al.[61] have proposed a micropump-based drug delivery device (Figure 3d). Drug-loaded reservoirs are thermally actuated resulting in controlled dispense.

sections.heading: 2.3. Nanocomposite Materials Used in Wearable Actuator Applications
sections.text:
Researchers have selected wearable actuator materials from a broader material group. Metal nanoparticles,[44,62] electroactive polymers,[32] conductive polymers,[17] ionic liquids (ILs),[34,63] and carbon-based materials[64] are highlights of the group. Silver nanowire transferred onto a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) film[18] has shown excellent stretchable heating properties. Fast thermal responses at their extremes (60 °C and 60% elongation) have perfectly positioned them as a wearable heater. AgNW was vacuum filtered onto a PDMS film and has shown good conformal coverage. Hsu et al.[49] dipped a commercial cotton cloth in AgNW solution before it was dried in vacuum. Among polymeric materials, conductive polymers had been in great interest for actuators. The electroactive properties of PEDOT:PSS have been utilized by most of the research groups. Zhou et al.[17] have wet-spun PEDOT:PSS fiber mat and doped it with ethylene glycol (EG) for enhanced mechanical properties. The actuator was fast-responsive and with 22 MPa of actuation stress. Not only the pristine polymer, composites[33] of carbon fiber, and IL with PEDOT:PSS have also shown significant actuating properties. Lin et al.[65] have simply dipped tissue paper into a polyionic liquid solution and soaked into an actuator. A summary of different materials and fabrication methods being used in wearable actuators is presented in Table 1. As summarized
in Table 1, the fabrication process is simple yet versatile and can break the ground for new designs and concepts in wearable electronics. They represent a wide range of applications over the body including the face, fingers, and hands (Figure 4).

sections.heading: 3.1. Overview
sections.text:
It is well known that sensor is a transducer that can convert one form of energy into another suitable form amenable for further processing, so it provides information on our physical, chemical, and biological environment for us.[66–68] Nowadays, the appearance of sensors in our daily life has revolutionized human’s living quality. Take a modern smart phone as an example, it can precisely fix, aggregate, and display position and orientation for users by integrating many sensors like gyroscope, accelerometer, magnetometer, and barometers in concert. But wearable sensors are expected to be the most practicable and prospective applications in the near future. Wearable devices equipped with a series of simplified sensors such as temperature,[69] strain sensors for posture and body movement,[70,71] biosensors for disease monitoring,[72–74] and multifunctional sensors for voice and facial expression detection[75] can preciously and real-timely feedback necessary body parameters to a central system.[76]

Wearable sensors are used to gather physiological and movement data like respiratory rate and the motion of leg, and then the information is transmitted to remote center via wireless communication.[81]

sections.heading: 3.2. Materials, Structures, and Methods in Wearable Sensors
sections.text:
The low flexibility and consistency of traditional sensor systems based on rigid metal and semiconductor materials remain a major challenge for wearable sensors attached to the human body for high accuracy monitoring.[82,83] Wearable sensors require novel approaches in material and structure design to possess high flexibility, stretchability, sensitivity, and wide sensing range.[84,85] Therefore, researchers have explored novel nanocomposites and nanomaterials for wearable sensors.[86] The choice of nanomaterials for wearable sensors mainly considers material properties, processing technology, and the possibility of large-scale production. Specially, 1D nanomaterials and nanocomposites including metallic NWs,[87,88] CNTs,[89,90]
or nanofibers[91,92] are being extensively used, because the high aspect ratio of 1D nanocomposites gives it the advantage of using smaller amount of materials to build a high-efficiency percolation conductive network.[93] On the other hand, 1D nanomaterials are ideal materials for designing transparent sensors that can possess highly transparent and stretchable conductive networks simultaneously.[94] In order to obtain the large-scale stretchability of nanomaterials, apart from using all intrinsically stretchable materials, many researchers have adopted advanced structural design strategies to improve system-level deformation behavior, such as wavy structures, horseshoe shapes, filamentary serpentine or fractal structures, and porous structures including sponge and foam.[95–97]
Currently, nanomaterial-based sensors are mainly prepared by incorporating nanomaterials into flexible or elastic substrate, such as a fiber, fabric, or polymer matrix.[98,99] For practical application, the manufacturing process of wearable sensors should be cost-effective, scalable, capable of large area, and easy production. To fabricate the wearable nanomaterial-based sensors, spin coating, spray coating, drop casting, dip coating, layer-by-layer assembly, vacuum filtration, and direct printing or writing techniques are among key interests of researchers currently.[100–104] Lou et al.[100] have electrospun poly(vinylidene fluoride-trifluoroethylene) (PVDF-TrFE) nanofibers and encapsulated them with reduced graphene oxide (rGO) to form a rapid responsive pressure sensor. Park et al.[101] have dip coated a fabric yarn to

Strain sensor based on CNT and shape memory polymers has reported an impressive strain rate over 700%[103] strain and vacuum filtration based graphene nanopaper prepared by Yan and team[104] has shown strain rate over 100%. Alternately, electrospinning is a simple and universal method for direct fabricating uniform micro-nanoscale fibers and has been widely developed. Electrospun polymer fibers have high surface area, adjustable surface topography, and superior mechanical properties. Furthermore, the functional electrospun nanofibers can be easily obtained through the combination of nanomaterials. To date, there are typically three approaches to fabricate electrospun functional nanofibers for the realization of sensitive wearable sensors: (i) directly electrospin conductive polymers into functional nanofibers,[105,106] such as PEDOT:PSS,[107] poly aniline (PANI),[108] (ii) directly electrospin nanofibers by doping poly mer spinning solutions with graphene oxide, carbon, CNTs, or Cu, Ag nanoparticles, or (iii) electrospin nonconductive polymers into nanofibers first and then coat them with conductive materials by electron beam evaporation,[109] electroless deposition, electrochemical polymerization, in situ polymerization,[92,110] and so on.

sections.heading: 3.3. Types of Sensors
sections.text:
Various innovative wearable sensors with excellent performance have been obtained by synthesizing nanomaterials and nanocomposites incorporating with existing nanomaterials.[111] In this section, some latest typical nanocomposite-based wearable sensors are summarized, including corresponding sensing mechanisms as well as material and structural designs to achieve high-performance wearable sensors. Recent advances of nanocomposite-based wearable sensors including strain,
pressure, temperature, and multifunctional sensors will be discussed in the following section.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Wearable Strain/Motion Sensors
sections.text:
Highly stretchable and sensitive wearable strain sensors that can detect full-range human movements are important components for many applications, including personalized health-care monitoring, continuous capturing of human daily physical activities, soft robotics, and human–machine.[84,101,112] High-performance wearable strain sensors must be capable of conformally integrating with any curvilinear and moving soft skins or clothing to accurately detect mechanical stimuli for disease diagnosis and health monitoring.[83] Additionally, they must possess the following characteristics: high stretchability for monitoring largescale human activities (such as stretching, torsion, and bending movements of the human limbs, ε > 100%), high sensitivity for detection of tiny-scale motions (such as delicate movements caused by heartbeat, pulse, swallowing, and facial microexpression, ε ≈ 0.1%), and fast response/recovery speeds for real-time monitoring.[104,113] Conventional strain sensors, mostly comprising metal and semiconductor films, possess brittle and rigid characteristics with limited stretchability (ε < 5%) and consequently they cannot be attached in intimate contact to various textiles and soft skins.[114] Currently, to solve these issues, various nanomaterials and nanocomposites (such as polymer nanofibers, metals or metal oxides nanowires, graphene, carbon nanotubes, and nanohybrid materials) are being employed to construct outstanding wearable strain sensor, since trimming down to nanoscale, nanostructures have an intrinsically large surface area in conjunction with excellent mechanical and electrical properties, thereby giving it the advantage of using smaller amount of active materials to build a high-efficiency percolation conductive network while maintaining high stretchability and then providing

a new opportunity to develop high-performance sensors[111,115–122] (Table 2). This part will review the recent progress of the strain sensors through their different conduction mechanisms, including resistive, capacitive, piezoelectric, and triboelectric.
Resistive Strain Sensors: In general, piezoresistive-type strain sensors lead to a resistance change when conductive materials are subjected to mechanical deformation in response to an applied strain. The most common strategy to obtain nanomaterial-based resistive strain sensors is to deposit or synthesize nanomaterials onto the surface or dope them into an elastomeric substrate (e.g., polyurethane (PU), PDMS, and polyester (PE)) for continuous conductive network forming.[97,123] The gauge factor (GF) is defined as (ΔR/R0)/ε, corresponding to the slope of the relative resistance variation of sensor under strain, where ε is the applied strain. The GFs mainly originate from transduction mechanisms such as piezoresistivity of materials themselves, disconnection between overlapped nanomaterials, crack propagation, tunneling effect, and structural design of strain sensors.[84,118,124–126] Applied strain on strain sensor can lead to the disconnection or sliding between nanomaterials and then decrease the contact area between nanomaterials, consequently increasing the electrical resistance. Currently, many strain sensors with high sensitivity based on the disconnection mechanism have been developed. Among them, graphene and nanowire network strain sensors have been extensively studied with high GFs and adjustable sensitivity. Figure 6a highlights an unique structural design of fish scale like for the construction of graphene-based strain sensor (FSG). This microstructure (made by strain/ release composite membrane with rGO film and elastic substrate) based on the disconnection mechanism enhances sensitivity (GF ≈ 16.2–150) of the strain sensor in conjunction with large stretchability (up to 82% strain). These characteristics allowed the FSG sensor to be attached on human skin to monitor human motions such as phonation recognition and wrist pulse (Figure 6b–d). The GF of strain sensors based on the disconnection mechanism can be controllable by varying the

density or thickness of nanomaterials.[84] Lower density nanomaterials resulted in reduced conductive networks and more effective disconnection between nanomaterials junctions and thus higher GFs.[101,127] Park and co-workers demonstrated a sandwich-structured stretchable strain sensor based on AgNWs and PDMS nanocomposite with adjustable GFs (2–14). In particular, the effect of the density of AgNW networks on the linearity and sensitivity of strain sensor has been analyzed by a numerical and experimental method.[88]
The cracked structures of the nanocomposite films greatly improved the sensitivity of the wearable strain sensors. Crack propagation in thin films induced by the external strain mainly contributes to change the resistance of strain sensors. The reversible micro/nanocracks enable dramatic decrease of the conductive pathway, which can control the GF of the sensor.[128,129] The use of nanomaterials based on crack propagation mechanism, such as metal particles, AgNWs, AuNWs, CNT, and graphene coated on flexible substrates, offers ideal GF ranges in working strain ranges.[87,130] By introducing different structures, complex strains are generated inside the elastic matrix during stretching, which results in different density distributions of the cracks and thus achieves the purpose of controlling sensitivity. For example, Amjadi et al. reported a
strain sensor based on the graphite elastomer films with reversible vertical microcrack structure. The sensing device exhibits ultrahigh GFs (up to 522.6) and stretchability (ε ≥ 50%)[131] (Figure 7a).
Capacitive Strain Sensors: Capacitive strain sensor is also a common type of sensor for flexible electronics. The capacitive strain sensors respond to the applied strain by the capacitance variation. A typical capacitive sensor is composed of a dielectric layer sandwiched between two electrodes, whose thickness varies upon stretching.[132] The parallel-plate configuration is the most popular architecture adapted in mainstream capacitive sensor designs as it is easy to construct and straight forward to model. In order to achieve conformal skin attachment, the electrodes of the sensor must meet the requirement of being stretchable.[83,133] Therefore, nanomaterial-based stretchable conductors are frequently used as the electrodes.[134] Particularly, various AgNW composites with advanced structures are intensively utilized in stretchable capacitive sensors by virtue of their cost effectiveness, high length–diameter ratio, ultrahigh conductivity, and good transparency.[135–137] In order to obtain higher mechanical sensitivity, higher stretchable dielectric layer materials with smaller mechanical modulus are needed, such as PDMS, PU, and Ecoflex. Piezoelectric Strain Sensors: Piezoelectric-type strain sensors rely on the piezoelectric effect of a particular type of solid materials, which contribute to transfer mechanical energy into output electricity. A variety of piezoelectric nanomaterials including zinc oxide (ZnO) nanowires, polylactic acid, PVDF-TrFE, and PVDF nanofibers have been utilized to exploit wearable strain sensors.[91,94,139,140] Piezoelectric strain sensors have the advantages of larger sensing range, fast response time, highly sensitivity to dynamic mechanical stimuli, and are typically selfpowered.[71] Based on these advantages, piezoelectric sensors have been extensively pursued in the detection of dynamic stimuli such as finger bending motion detection, vibration, sound and slip.[86,141] Figure 7e demonstrates a strain sensor array composed of piezopotential nanogenerators (strain sensing component) and graphene transistors. The piezopotential produced by P(VDF-TrFE) piezoelectric materials is effectively coupled to the conductive paths of the graphene transistor through dielectric layer upon external mechanical stimuli. In this issue, the piezopotential controls the conductance of the graphene transistors. The sensor array demonstrated ultrahigh GF (up to 389), a ultralow detectable strain of 0.008%, which has a good application prospect in real-time human health-care monitoring.[120] Figure 7f presents a high-performance self-powered e-skin based on novel piezoelectric ZnO/PVDF nanostructures
with flexible fabric substrate. The ZnO/PVDF nanostructures showed enhanced piezoelectric output properties and then can detect human elbow bending, by utilizing the synergistic piezoelectric effect of PVDF and ZnO.[142] In another work, a piezoelectric nanogenerator with single-electrode configuration was developed by electrospun PVDF nanofibers which enables steady-state external strain sensing (Figure 7g). The flexible device can be attached on the wrist for sensing human movement such as running and joint bending based on the output voltage changes, which is contributed by piezoelectric and pyroelectric effects of the electrospun PVDF nanofibers.[143] In conclusion, a nanomaterial-based piezoelectric strain sensing device usually exhibited high sensitivity with rapid response speed and ultralow power consumption, but is limited in excellent stretchability.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Wearable Pressure Sensors
sections.text:
The wearable pressure sensor with excellent sensitivity can simulate the properties of human skin by generating electrical signals to sense the applied pressure, which exhibits extensive potential applications in artificial smart systems and human physiological signal monitoring.[91] Pressure sensors employ similar physical transduction principles as strain sensors, including piezoresistive, capacitance, piezoelectric, and triboelectric type. Especially, resistive effect (resistance varies with pressure) and capacitive effect (capacitance varies with pressure) have been mostly adopted for the design of pressure sensor. The resistive-type sensing device mainly depends on the variation in geometry structure, tunneling resistance or contact resistance to respond to the applied pressure. Recently, piezoresistive pressure sensors have been extensively exploited due to their simple preparation technology and device structure, easy read-out signal, and broad sensing range.[144] Various emerging nanomaterials and nanocomposites with novel geometrical microstructures have been investigated to construct resistive pressure sensors with outstanding performance. However, most conventional resistive-type sensors with planar composite structure usually exhibit poor sensing performance, and hence highly sensitive networks for pressure sensing can be formed using novel geometrical microstructures, including interlocked structures,[145] percolative networks of nanomaterials[146] (e.g., CNTs, NWs, and rGO), patterned microstructures,[147] porous structures[97,148] (e.g., hollow sphere, sponges, and foams), conductive fibers,[149] and so forth. For example, Figure 8a,b shows a resistive pressure sensor based on a patterned elastic microstructure. The monolayer graphene was deposited on a bioinspired PDMS hierarchical microstructure structure as a pressure sensing system. Notably, the sensor displayed a high linear sensitivity of 8.5 kPa−1 from 0 to 12 kPa (Figure 8c). The durability test of 10 000 cycles demonstrated the device with better stability and reliability.[150]
In particular, these sensors fabricated by electrospun nanofiber films and fabric also achieved excellent piezoresistive response. A pressure sensor composed of PVDF@ rGO nanofiber films exhibited a sensitivity up to 15.6 kPa−1, lower detection limit of 1.2 Pa, and working voltage of 1 V[100] (Figure 8d,e).

For instance, a capacitive touch sensory system was developed with stretchable graphene-based transparent electrodes. The sensor highlighted the multicontact and the 3D sensing properties under the condition of higher deformation. In addition, it simultaneously realized the good sensing performances under the mode of contact and noncontact surface sensing.[151] In order to improve the pressure sensitivity, the use of high deformable dielectric material or the designing of a dielectric material into an ideal structure like porous microstructures can be a good solution and can improve the response time due to its reduced viscoelastic deformation.[152,153] Figure 8f,g highlights a capacitive pressure sensor based on electrospun porous nanofiber. The dielectric layer of the sensor employed core–shell PDMS/PVDFHFP elastic nanofiber mats. sections.heading: 3.3.3. Wearable Temperature Sensors
sections.text:
Body temperature is a fundamental and vital parameter in an effort to monitor various types of illnesses/diseases (e.g., fever, infection, heat stroke, and malignant tumor), physiological status, etc. Since it may vary both temporally and spatially as a result of heat transfer between the biological organs and the environment, body temperature is needed to be monitored in real time with high sensitivity and accuracy.[157,158] As one of the important sensing components for the artificially electronic skins, wearable temperature sensor should possess high sensitivity and accuracy, fast response, wide sensing range (25–40 °C), and long-time stability and repeatability against ambient influences.[159,160]Currently, the wearable temperature sensors have also adopted various nanomaterials including CNT, graphene, conductive polymers (such as PEDOT:PSS, PPy, and polyaniline) and Ni, Ag, Cu metallic nanoparticles and nanowires as the thermal sensing elements.[69,71,97,157,161] The thermoresistive, thermoelectric, and pyroelectric effects are utilized in wearable temperature sensors for temperature measurement. For instance, Figure 9a shows a silk-based temperature sensor with electrospun carbon nanofiber membranes used directly as the sensing element. Owing to the thermoresistive effect, the sensor can detect the temperature variation by utilizing the temperature dependence of the film resistance (Figure 9b). The device shows the advantages of excellent sensitivity, fast response speed, and stable sensing performance under deformation.[161] Hong et al. reported a stretchable temperature sensor based on polyaniline nanofibers and CNT transistors, which exhibited excellent and stable sensitivity even under tensile strain[69] (Figure 9c,d). Graphene oxide foam was employed as a thermoelectric temperature sensing element without external power supply.[146] The sensor itself can convert the difference in temperature to a current signal through the

sections.heading: 3.3.4. Wearable Multifunctional Sensors
sections.text:
As portable electronic devices get popularized significantly, the functionality of the sensor is not only limited to a single stimulus but is also expected to be spread over a wide band of physical stimuli. Simultaneous differentiation is also a required functionality together with the integrated diversity among different stimuli like strain, twist, temperature, light, humidity, and the environmental gasses.[162–165] To date, many research reports have started to develop multifunctional wearable sensors for tracking human motions by real-time continuous signals. The multimodal and multifunctional sensor can be realized by assembling sensors with various functions, which can simplify the integration of sensors and miniaturize their volume. For example, Figure 10a,b demonstrates an ultrasensitive sensor with pressure and temperature sensing, which employs the piezoresistive and thermoresistive effect of PANI hollow nanospheres and CNT active composite. In particular, the continuous sensing and mapping of pressure and temperature changes can be accurately detected by resistive variation[163] (Figure 10c). In another work, a self-powered multifunctional sensor was fabricated by employing rGO/PVDF nanofibers as both the sensing and energy storage elements, which integrated with pressure and gas sensor as well as photo detector to detect environmental conditions and human physiological signals (Figure 10d–f). The design of multifunctional wearable sensor not only avoids the separate use of different materials, but also realizes the integration of different sensors in a very simple and efficient way.[91] In response to the ongoing challenges for

sections.heading: 3.4. Applications of Wearable Sensors
sections.text: Placement of wearable sensors is flexible. They can either be placed on clothes or attached to the body like finger, wrist, arm, throat, chest, and leg. Others can be embedded into wearing accessories such as gloves, watches, earrings, necklaces, brooches, and so on. In recent years, wearable sensors have exhibited tremendous potential in a broad range of applications. In this sector, we will focus on the applications of wearable sensors in health-care monitoring, human body movements detection.

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Health Monitoring
sections.text:
Recently, there has been extensive application of wearable devices integrated with various sensors in health monitoring. They can continuously sense, acquire, analyze, and store data associated with human physiological parameters including body temperature, blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and so on, which provides long-term guidance and feedback about health condition for users.[73,168] In general, these sensors are directly attached to soft and curvilinear surfaces of
human skin for accurate and real-time detection, which then demands sensors to be stretchable, flexible, biocompatible, light weight, and naturally conformal to the surface of the skins with minimal user awareness.[169] Human body temperature is an important parameter to assess the health condition. Figure 11a gives an example that an electronic sensor platform softly and reversibly laminated at wounds can provide highly accurate, quantitative data of relevance to the management of surgical wound healing.[169] Heart rate is also a most common physiological parameter, which plays a critical role in health and disease of human. There are many methods to measure the heart rate of a person such as sound-based technology[74] and methods based on changes in the brightness of a person’s face.[170] A graphene strain sensor attached to the chest can also measure relative change of resistance of the respiratory during normal and exercise, respectively, shown in Figure 11b.[171] Figure 11c shows a PVDF plastic wrap transparent capacitive pressure sensor. The capacitance of sensor exhibited an excellent match in response to pressure changes and well-defined detection of the cyclic change in pressure. The cost-effective manner to fabricate the sensor is highly expected.[172]

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Human Movement Monitoring
sections.text:
Wearable sensors have been used extensively to detect human movements in people’s daily life, including assistive living, rehabilitation, and surveillance. Movements monitoring can be broadly divided into two categories: monitoring of large-scale movements such as bending of the knees, hands, and fingers, and monitoring of small-scale movements like subtle motions

of throat and chest while swallowing and breathing.[101] Therefore, high sensitivity and broad sensing range are indispensable to these wearable sensors.[173] To date, various stretchable strain sensors and pressure sensors have been widely used to monitor human movements.[171,174,175] A strain sensor based on graphene woven fabrics-PDMS-medical tape film possessed an extremely high gauge factor 106 under high strains (>7%) and 35 under small strain of 0.2%, which means that resistance change is very sensitive to tiny deformations. It can be equipped at various positions such as wrist, soundtrack, and canthus to detect pulse, phonation, blink, expression changes, and so on (Figure 12a).[171] Recognizing emotional expressions such as laughing,[75,176] angry,[75] eyeball rolls,[75,176] and others[130,177] has been achieved by employing strain sensors to detect the associated skin movements. For example, as shown in Figure 12b, an Ag nanoparticle curve-based strain sensor attached to human facial skin was used to record and distinguish eight main facial expressions of emotion.[75] The clothing-integrated sensors have received more attention because these do not restrict motion and are also an excellent option for repeatable and sharable use. By integrating the flexible pressure sensor with a sport shoe and waist belt, realtime sport data including walking and running pace and health condition like breathing were obtained.[77] A CNT-based strain sensor can be assembled on commercial adhesive bandages, stockings, and gloves to detect different types of human motion such as movement, typing, breathing, and speech, as shown in Figure 12c,d.[113]

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Wearable electronics is a subject undergoing intense research currently due to a number of factors. Sensors and actuators are key categories of wearable electronics, as they are capable of developing smart wearables that can actively interact with both the user and environment. Different wearable actuators targeting personal comfort, expanded physical capabilities, therapeutic applications, and drug delivery systems were discussed in this review while a huge range of sensors including health and human movement monitoring sensors are presented under wearable sensors category. Comparatively, wearable actuators are still at their early development stages due to the limitations on materials and ability to control their functionalities. Different material groups like polymers, carbon nanomaterials, and metal-based nanomaterials have already been used in wearable sensors and actuators because of their different functionalities. In this review, current research highlights based on nanomaterials in wearable actuators and sensors are also listed down and some selected cases are discussed briefly. Polymerbased materials and material groups were in spotlight for most

The selection of suitable material has always been a subject of desired functionality and still there exists a potential for new materials or composites. As the range of functionalities is continuously growing for both wearable sensors and actuators, it is highly desired to identify novel materials or composites of materials that can fulfill the demand.

metadata.abstractText: Powered by market hype, trends among youth, and enormous funds, wearable technology has propelled itself as one of the most discussed topics in the field during past few years. A number of different companies representing all throughout the world have already entered into the market with hundreds of different products like smart watches, fitness trackers, smart garments, and even different smart medical attachments. Together with the evolution of digital health care, the wearable electronics field has evolved rapidly during the past few years and is expected to be expanded even further within the first few years of the next decade. As the next stage of wearables is predicted to move toward integrated wearables, nanomaterials and nanocomposites are in the spotlight of the search for novel concepts for integration. In addition, the conversion of current devices and attachment-based wearables into integrated technology may involve a significant size reduction while retaining their functional capabilities. Nanomaterialbased wearable sensors have already marked their presence with a significant distinction while nanomaterial-based wearable actuators are still at their embryonic stage. This review looks into the contribution of nanomaterials and nanocomposites to wearable technology with a focus on wearable sensors and actuators. Wearable Electronics
